reasoning:
The critique targets one illustrative move in §2.3: using “preference engineering” to argue that even an abundant, preference-satisfied society could still be morally catastrophic. This is relevant to the paper’s broader “eutopia is fragile / no easy eutopia” thesis, but it is not load-bearing: the paper offers many other independent fragility mechanisms (population ethics, digital beings’ rights, bads/goods aggregation, resource allocation, scale, etc.), and much of the argument in §3 aims to show fussiness across many moral views, not hinging on this specific case. So centrality is modest.

On strength: the critique plausibly identifies a tension: if the interlocutor is genuinely “easygoing liberal / preference-satisfactionist,” then calling preference-adapted satisfaction “tragically mediocre” risks smuggling in objective-list or external standards. This undercuts that particular example’s force as a counterexample to easygoing liberalism. However, the paper could reply that (i) it is intentionally operating under moral pluralism/uncertainty and only needs some plausible views on which this is catastrophic, or (ii) even procedural liberalism may condemn certain preference-engineering pathways (coercion, manipulation, time-inconsistency). Because the critique mainly shows under-arguedness/overreach in one example rather than refuting the general fragility claim, strength is moderate.

Correctness is fairly high: it accurately characterizes a potential equivocation between “getting what they want” and an evaluator’s external value standard, and its proposed fixes are reasonable. It slightly overstates the extent to which the paper “uses (a) then evaluates with (b)” because the paper is explicitly canvassing many moral perspectives and is not committed to preference-satisfactionism; still, the local point stands. Clarity is high and the critique is tightly focused with little dead weight.
title: Preference satisfaction framework conflicts with external judgments of moral loss
